title: JavaCollectionsFrameworkList - Q0001
text: Which package contains the List interface?
explanation: The List interface is part of the java.util package.

title: JavaCollectionsFrameworkList - Q0002
text: Which of the following interfaces does List extend?
explanation: The List interface extends the Collection interface.

title: JavaCollectionsFrameworkList - Q0003
text: Which of the following is true about the List interface?
explanation: The List interface allows duplicate elements and maintains insertion order.

title: JavaCollectionsFrameworkList - Q0004
text: Which of the following is true about the order of elements in a List?
explanation: List maintains the order in which elements are inserted.

title: JavaCollectionsFrameworkList - Q0005
text: Which of the following classes implement the List interface?
explanation: ArrayList, LinkedList, Vector, and Stack are implementations of the List interface.

title: JavaCollectionsFrameworkList - Q0006
text: Which of the following methods adds an element at a specific index in a List?
explanation: The add(int index, E element) method inserts an element at a specific position in the list.

title: JavaCollectionsFrameworkList - Q0007
text: Which of the following methods retrieves an element at a specific index?
explanation: The get(int index) method retrieves the element at the specified index.

title: JavaCollectionsFrameworkList - Q0008
text: Which of the following methods replaces an element at a specific index?
explanation: The set(int index, E element) method replaces the element at the specified index.

title: JavaCollectionsFrameworkList - Q0009
text: Which of the following methods returns the index of the first occurrence of an element?
explanation: The indexOf(Object o) method returns the index of the first occurrence of the specified element.

title: JavaCollectionsFrameworkList - Q0010
text: Which of the following methods returns the index of the last occurrence of an element?
explanation: The lastIndexOf(Object o) method returns the index of the last occurrence of the specified element.

title: JavaCollectionsFrameworkList - Q0011
text: Which of the following methods removes an element at a specific index?
explanation: The remove(int index) method removes the element at the specified index.

title: JavaCollectionsFrameworkList - Q0012
text: Which of the following methods returns a portion of the list between two indices?
explanation: The subList(int fromIndex, int toIndex) method returns a view of the portion of the list between the specified indices.

title: JavaCollectionsFrameworkList - Q0013
text: Which of the following is true about the List interface and null elements?

options.text: List does not allow null elements
List allows only one null element
List allows null elements only at the end

explanation: Most List implementations, such as ArrayList, allow null elements.

title: JavaCollectionsFrameworkList - Q0014
text: Which of the following is true about the List interface and duplicates?

options.text: List throws an exception for duplicates

explanation: The List interface allows duplicate elements.

title: JavaCollectionsFrameworkList - Q0015
text: Which of the following is true about the List interface and random access?

options.text: Vector does not support random access

explanation: ArrayList provides fast random access because it is backed by an array.

title: JavaCollectionsFrameworkList - Q0016
text: Which of the following is true about the List interface and iteration?

options.text: List provides a ListIterator for bidirectional traversal

explanation: The List interface provides a ListIterator that supports bidirectional traversal.

title: JavaCollectionsFrameworkList - Q0017
text: Which of the following methods returns a ListIterator?
explanation: The listIterator() method returns a ListIterator for traversing the list.

title: JavaCollectionsFrameworkList - Q0018
text: Which of the following is true about the List interface and synchronization?

options.text: List is not synchronized by default

explanation: The List interface is not synchronized by default; synchronization can be achieved using Collections.synchronizedList().

title: JavaCollectionsFrameworkList - Q0019
text: Which of the following methods can be used to synchronize a List?
explanation: The Collections.synchronizedList() method returns a synchronized (thread-safe) list.

title: JavaCollectionsFrameworkList - Q0020
text: Which of the following is true about the List interface and immutability?

options.text: Lists can be made unmodifiable using Collections.unmodifiableList()

explanation: Lists can be made unmodifiable using the Collections.unmodifiableList() method.

title: JavaCollectionsFrameworkList - Q0021
text: Which of the following methods adds all elements from another list?
explanation: The addAll(Collection c) method adds all elements from another collection to the list.

title: JavaCollectionsFrameworkList - Q0022
text: Which of the following methods removes all elements from a list?
explanation: The clear() method removes all elements from the list.

title: JavaCollectionsFrameworkList - Q0023
text: Which of the following methods checks if a list contains a specific element?
explanation: The contains(Object o) method checks if a specific element exists in the list.

title: JavaCollectionsFrameworkList - Q0024
text: Which of the following methods returns the number of elements in a list?
explanation: The size() method returns the number of elements in the list.

title: JavaCollectionsFrameworkList - Q0025
text: Which of the following methods checks if a list is empty?
explanation: The isEmpty() method returns true if the list contains no elements.

title: JavaCollectionsFrameworkList - Q0026
text: Which of the following methods converts a list into an array?
explanation: The toArray() method converts the list into an array.

title: JavaCollectionsFrameworkList - Q0027
text: Which of the following methods compares two lists for equality?
explanation: The equals(Object o) method compares two lists for equality based on their elements and order.

title: JavaCollectionsFrameworkList - Q0028
text: Which of the following methods returns a stream of elements from a list?
explanation: The stream() method returns a sequential Stream with the list as its source.

title: JavaCollectionsFrameworkList - Q0029
text: Which of the following methods removes elements that satisfy a given condition?
explanation: The removeIf(Predicate filter) method removes all elements that satisfy the given condition.

title: JavaCollectionsFrameworkList - Q0030
text: Which of the following methods was added in Java 8 for iteration?
explanation: The forEach(Consumer action) method was added in Java 8 to perform an action for each element.

title: JavaCollectionsFrameworkList - Q0031
text: Which of the following is true about the List interface and random access?

options.text: Vector does not support random access
Stack does not support random access

explanation: ArrayList implements the RandomAccess interface for fast random access.

title: JavaCollectionsFrameworkList - Q0032
text: Which of the following is true about the List interface and fail-fast behavior?

options.text: Iterators of most List implementations are fail-fast

explanation: Iterators of most List implementations are fail-fast and throw ConcurrentModificationException if modified during iteration.

title: JavaCollectionsFrameworkList - Q0033
text: Which of the following is true about the List interface and sorting?

options.text: Collections.sort() can be used to sort a List

explanation: The Collections.sort() method can be used to sort a List.

title: JavaCollectionsFrameworkList - Q0034
text: Which of the following is true about the List interface and subList()?

options.text: subList() returns a view of the specified range
subList() returns a copy of the specified range
subList() removes elements from the list

explanation: The subList() method returns a view of the specified range, not a copy.

title: JavaCollectionsFrameworkList - Q0035
text: Which of the following is true about the List interface and immutability?
explanation: The List.of() method introduced in Java 9 creates an immutable list.

title: JavaCollectionsFrameworkList - Q0036
text: Which of the following is true about the List interface and null elements in List.of()?

options.text: List.of() does not allow null elements
List.of() replaces null with empty string

explanation: The List.of() method does not allow null elements and throws NullPointerException if null is passed.

title: JavaCollectionsFrameworkList - Q0037
text: Which of the following is true about the List interface and equals()?

options.text: equals() compares lists based on elements and order

explanation: The equals() method compares lists based on their elements and order.

title: JavaCollectionsFrameworkList - Q0038
text: Which of the following is true about the List interface and hashCode()?

options.text: hashCode() is based on the elements and their order
hashCode() is based only on size

explanation: The hashCode() method of a List is based on the elements and their order.

title: JavaCollectionsFrameworkList - Q0039
text: Which of the following is true about the List interface and iteration order?
explanation: List maintains the order in which elements are inserted.

title: JavaCollectionsFrameworkList - Q0040
text: Which of the following is true about the List interface and duplicates?

options.text: List throws an exception for duplicates

explanation: The List interface allows duplicate elements.

title: JavaCollectionsFrameworkList - Q0041
text: Which of the following is true about the List interface and thread safety?

options.text: List is not thread-safe by default

explanation: The List interface is not thread-safe by default; synchronization can be achieved using Collections.synchronizedList().

title: JavaCollectionsFrameworkList - Q0042
text: Which of the following is true about the List interface and fail-fast iterators?
explanation: Fail-fast iterators throw ConcurrentModificationException if the list is modified during iteration.

title: JavaCollectionsFrameworkList - Q0043
text: Which of the following is true about the List interface and ListIterator?
explanation: ListIterator allows bidirectional traversal and modification of the list.

title: JavaCollectionsFrameworkList - Q0044
text: Which of the following is true about the List interface and subList() modifications?

options.text: Changes in subList() reflect in the original list
Changes in subList() do not affect the original list
subList() creates a new independent list

explanation: Changes made to the subList() view are reflected in the original list.

title: JavaCollectionsFrameworkList - Q0045
text: Which of the following is true about the List interface and index-based access?

options.text: List does not support index-based access

explanation: The List interface supports index-based access to elements.

title: JavaCollectionsFrameworkList - Q0046
text: Which of the following is true about the List interface and removeAll()?

options.text: removeAll() removes all elements that are also in another collection

explanation: The removeAll() method removes all elements that are also contained in another collection.

title: JavaCollectionsFrameworkList - Q0047
text: Which of the following is true about the List interface and retainAll()?

options.text: retainAll() keeps only elements present in another collection

explanation: The retainAll() method retains only the elements that are also contained in another collection.

title: JavaCollectionsFrameworkList - Q0048
text: Which of the following is true about the List interface and containsAll()?

options.text: containsAll() checks if all elements of another collection are present

explanation: The containsAll() method checks if all elements of another collection are present in the list.

title: JavaCollectionsFrameworkList - Q0049
text: Which of the following is true about the List interface and parallelStream()?

options.text: parallelStream() returns a parallel stream of elements

explanation: The parallelStream() method returns a parallel stream for concurrent processing of elements.

title: JavaCollectionsFrameworkList - Q0050
text: Which of the following best describes the List interface?

options.text: An ordered collection that allows duplicates and provides index-based access
An unordered collection that disallows duplicates
A collection that stores unique elements only

explanation: The List interface represents an ordered collection that allows duplicates and provides index-based access.
